The tiny town of Preston, Kansas, once boasted a very active Main Street with two grocery stores, a post office, a cafe, a drugstore and a filling station.

In fact, only 170 people live here.
Boarded-up buildings line either side of Main Street.
A City Hall and senior center remain within view of two towering grain elevators.
Ken Stanton plans to change much of that.
The 53-year-old mortician with a warm and easy smile has been in the funeral business for 18 years.
He is no stranger to Preston.
For 35 years, he and his wife, Donna, have come here to visit relatives.
Donna's father dreamed of a revitalized Preston, and Stanton embraced that dream.
I saw this little town, and I saw some pictures of it back in the early 1900s and saw what it was, and believed that this town could thrive again.
So a year ago, he bought the run-down bar and grill on Main Street to turn it into a mortuary and crematorium.
Today, Stanton and brother-in-law Mike Saldan are surveying the gutted 94-year-old brick building.
